lines.text: It's a philosophy. A poetics. A politics, if you will. A literature of protest. A novel of ideas. A pornographic magazine of truly comic book proportions. It is, in the end, whatever the hell I want it to be. And when I'm through with it it's going to blow a hole this wide straight through the world's own idea of itself.
[bottles breaking]
They're throwing bottles at your house. Come on. Let's go break their arms.
I've been bad. Repeatedly.
I worked, while you sat back and comfortably dismissed the outside world as too shallow, stupid and mean to appreciate your ideas.
Is that such a priority? Is that some sort of measure of a man's worth? To drag what's best in him out into the street so every average slob with some pretense to taste can poke it with a stick?
Maybe. Maybe it is.
An honest man is always in trouble, remember that Simon.
Opportunity will move out of the way to let a man pass it by.
The world is full of shit indeed.
Certain work needs to be experienced all at once in order for one to appreciate the full force of it's character.
Be reasonable.
Why?
I can't work for a living, Simon, it's impossible. I've tried once. My genius will be wasted trying to make ends meet. This is how great men topple, Simon.
"They're... they're the donut people." Got it?
It's a pornographic magazine of truly comic book proportions!
You can't go to work! You have to stay home and write!
Look, Simon, I made love to your mother about half an hour ago, and now I'm beginning to think that maybe it wasn't such a good idea.
We gotta talk. What the hell were you trying to do when you wrote this thing?
Nothing.
Well, you know, you wrote it in a kind of iambic pentameter.
Iambic what?

Verse. Look. In my opinion, this is pretty powerful stuff. Though your spelling is Neanderthal and your reasoning a little naive, your instincts are profound. But the whole thing needs to be given a more cohesive shape. It can be expanded, followed through, unified. Do you see what I'm getting at? Are you willing to commit yourself to this? To really work on it? To give it its due in the face of adversity and discouragement? To rise to the challenge you yourself have set? And don't give me that wonderstruck "I'm only a humble garbage man" bullshit, either.
It hurts to breathe.
Of course it does.
Perhaps I wasn't made to walk through shit.
We know we have fallen, for we know who we are.
You can't argue about taste.
[reading porn magazines]
I learn so much from these magazines Mr. Dang, and I refuse to discriminate between modes of knowing.
A prophet is seldom heeded in his own land.

One of you poor, underpaid jerks is gonna have an eye ripped out of its socket. I promise. It's a small thing perhaps, all things considered, but I will succeed, because it's the only thing I have left to do in this world. So why don't you just take a good look at one another one last time, and think it over a few minutes more."

[pause]
And then what happened?
Well. Here I am, still, after all.

[Glaring at Henry, while taking their 5 year old son, Ned, from the bar where Henry took him]
Ned, have you been drinking?
His throat hurt from smoking.
[Fay punches Henry in the gut, hard]
I don't discriminate between different ways of knowing.

In Rome today, the Pope issued a message of hope for believers in their fight against what he termed the godless and lost. He did not mention Simon Grimm by name, but offered a prayer for the young, whom he described as sadly in need of faith and not the illusion of conviction offered by rock music, drugs and contemporary poetry.
She was an ugly and mean-spirited kid, but she knew how to play upon my weaknesses, which, I admit, are deep and many.
You can't put a fence around a man's soul, we think and feel where and when we think and feel. We are servants of our muse and we toil where she commands.
How old do you think I am?
You look young.
How young?
I don't know. Young.
But how? I mean, do I look more like 20 or, y'know, 30.

[thinks hard]
30.

Can you sit there, look me straight in the eye and tell me that you don't think this poem is great? That it is not at once a poem of great lyrical beauty and ethical depth; that it is not a genuine, highly profound meditation on the miracle of existence?
*Can* you?
No. I can't.
So you see you have no choice.
Only someone who really cares doubts.
Are you a registered voter?
Don't you dare talk to me that way!

little. And what little there is to be said is immense. Or, in other words, follow your own genius to where it leads without regard for the apparent needs of the world at large, which, in fact, has no needs as such, but, rather, moments of exhaustion in which it is incapable of prejudice. We can only hope to collide with these moments of unselfconsciousness. This divine fatigue. This...
Push over.
'Nous savons que nous avons chuté parce que nous savons qui nous sommes.' 'We know we have fallen because we know who we are.

[skeptically]
When were you in Paris?
That's beside the point. But did they listen to me? Of course not!
